newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech Nomura unit takes Radegast stake.
newsitem.headline: Czech Nomura unit takes Radegast stake.

text.p: Nomura Capital s.r.o., a Czech subsidiary of Nomura International plc, acquired a 12.58 percent stake in Czech brewer Pivovar Radegast a.s., according to the latest filings with the Czech Central Securities Registry (SCP).
The SCP records also showed that Czech bank IPB a.s. reduced its stake in the brewer from 19.53 percent on June 30 to below 10 percent on July 3.

Meanwhile, records of transactions at the SCP reveal that 100,000 Radegast shares, a number equal to the stake Nomura acquired, traded over-the-counter in a block at 6,150 crowns per share on June 30. SCP records do not show counterparties in trades.

When asked about the transaction, IPB spokesman Jan Rezek would not directly confirm the transaction, but he told Reuters: "It can be quite easily deduced from the circumstances." He referred any further comment to Nomura.
Radegast shares rose 21 crowns to 3,561 at the Prague Stock Exchange on Thursday.
The Czech daily Mlada Fronta Dnes quoted a bank spokesman as saying that the bank has divested stakes in several large comanies recently.
Britain's Bass plc holds a 33 percent stake in Radegast, and has revealed its intentions to increase its holdings in the company.
Nomura recently has been working closely in financial deals with IPB, and its subsidiary Nutshell s.r.o. holds a five percet stake in the Czech bank.
Nomura is also widely expected to win a Czech government tender to take a 36 percent stake in the bank.
Rezek said the bank's long-term strategy was divesting of its holdings in companies through standard trade operations.
He did confirm a report in the Czech daily Mlada Fronta on Thursday that IPB had divested stakes in another brewer, Plzensky Prazdroj a.s. to Netherland's registered Quartermaine Investment Fund.

He also confirmed said that stakes in the ceramics factory Chlumcanske Keramicke Zavody a.s. and the malt trading firm Obchodni Sladovny were sold to Quartermaine as well, and that a stake in porcelain producer Karlovarsky Porcelan was divested to another party.
He declined further comment on Quartermaine, based in Rotterdam.
